Honestly, I don't understand how anyone can think this game is great, because it's just shallow, flawed, and poorly made in so many ways.

I don't want to spoil, so here's just spoiler-free criticism (there's a lot more criticism though!):

3 of the included investigators are simply not playable! It's simple math: If you get 2 damage per round from an opponent and only take 5 damage yourself, but conversely you need 3 rounds to kill the opponent....WTF?

Deckbuilding? Absolute exaggeration! There are so few different cards in here, and they are so repetitive, that it doesn't deserve the term deckbuilding at all. There are far better ones on the market!

And finally: it's an absolute game of chance. Whether you make it to the second scenario (if you have chosen the right investigator and survive the first scenario) is a matter of luck. Buy dice and think of a shallow story around it, it's 10 times cheaper and has the same level of this "game".

***UPDATE 2021: I finally managed to play my way through to the end of this trashfire. Never have I encountered game design that is so lazy, so unplaytested, and harboring so much contempt toward the players. This game is in desperate need of streamlining, or better yet, set it all on fire and start again from scratch, or better still, don't, just make a different game entirely. Absolute waste of time, I will never buy another FF game. ***

No the card game is death by a thousand cuts which you see coming from miles away. For example fighting a monster with a absurd amount of health knowing that it is LITERALLY impossible to defeat. Even with the best weapons you might do 2-3 damage, but are receiving 2-3 damage each round. Simple math tells me I am going to lose this exchange when it has X health and I have X-4. I guess I should just resign myself to always having to you know resign, but how is that fun? Constantly knowing that the best I can do it hopefully not die and leave the game early and ready the crap ending?

All of that being said I love the actual board games, especially Eldritch Horror.

A good game, but I cannot condone any more the predatory practices of FFG, and their attitude towards hobby gaming. The core game offers zero possibilities to deckbuild (a central mechanism of AHtcg), and you can only play some pairs of the provided investigators due to lack of provided cards. Considering that this is a card game, and that they likely get their cards for dirt cheap prices, this is even more infuriating. A second deck of cards would have cost them almost nothing. An insert would have also cost them just a little. Heck, they don't even provide baggies... Instead, they chose to sell you another product, a box to properly fit all cards, together with the thin "nightmare decks". What rubbish...

This is lack of respect. Pass hard, there are so many equally great games from companies that respect you as a consumer and the hobby in general.

Own the base game, the complete Dunwich Legacy, Curse of the Roogaroo & Carnevale. Played the base game and the first four scenarios from Dunwich Legacy before giving up.

What an obnoxious, unpleasant little game. The narrative component is pedestrian at best and full of holes and absurdities, chief among them being the underlying system of deck building (now wait a minute, I know I packed in that lightning gun somewhere, now where on earth could it be...). What exactly is it that you are doing with the "resource" action in the middle of nowhere? It's not so much that you have to fill in the gaps created by the abstractions in the design, it's more that the level of absurdity precludes you from doing so. So the game essentially boils down to a series of annoying little optimization puzzles tied together by a little bit of blurb at the beginning/end of each scenario. The narrative is not emergent, it's tacked on.

There is no immersion since you're focusing on a bunch of mechanisms that basically take you away from the story, and the rules are so full of holes and so utterly disorganized (literally nothing is where you would expect to find it) that well into your fourth or fifth scenario, you will still have to stop the game now and again to check something that's not covered in the learn to play booklet. It's impossible to learn the game beforehand because the "learn to play guide" is incomplete, and the "rules reference" booklet is organized alphabetically (and also incomplete, albeit a little less so than the other booklet). Since each scenario has very limited replayability (I see none at all, but I am told otherwise), it's not a trivial point that the experience has to be spoiled by the sheer carelessness of FFG's rule writers. It's not a complicated game, it didn't have to be so sloppy.

It's no fun to lose (which will happen a lot), and it's even less fun to have to go through the motions of playing the same scenario multiple times since the puzzles are not even that interesting once you know the layout of the locations and the composition of the deck. You can always accept the "no resolution" a.k.a "you're dead" resolution, but how satisfying is that? I'm dead but my character somehow comes back from the grave to fight another day?

The game I hear is all about investing mountains of cash so that you can unlock its deck-building aspect, which apparently is crucial to enjoyment. Well then congrats to FFG and everyone involved for a monumental cash grab that would do Games Workshop proud.

Forgive me. I normally do not post game reviews, but I feel moved to write this one.

As God is my witness, I will never understand the froth and hype for this game. This game is undoubtedly one of the worst Lovecraft-based games, if not one of the worst games, in general, I have ever played.

The ONLY positive is the artwork. The game is pedantic and slow. Any narrative is accidental. Essentially, players are following little symbols and pulling from a bag of chance that is heavily weighted against the players. Now, let me clarify. A challenging game is a good game. This game isn't that. This game is consistent and tiresome player-loss and scenario re-do's until the players accidentally succeed...via chance bag draws. This game is not only "not fun." It is the opposite of fun.

It's awful. Truly bad.

Avoid it.

I don’t understand how this game is rated so well. It’s overly complicated to learn, it feels like it wants to be a board game, but elected for a card format for… reasons?

These things would be forgivable if the game were at least fun, but it’s not. With the “standard” Chaos Token set, 75% of the tokens are negative outcomes, and 12.5% are neutral, meaning that you often have to overcompensate with resources to avoid failing too often, making the game ridiculously difficult on just the “standard” difficulty.

The deck building aspect is mediocre at best, and the storyline is uninspired (though not bad.)

You never have any turns where you’re like “Heck yeah, that was awesome” but have plenty of turns where the layers of randomness can (and will) just absolutely obliterate you. There’s randomness in your deck, the encounter deck, and all the skill tests, but no randomness to monster attacks/damage.

Just not a fun game. Go play Gloomhaven instead. Also complicated, but actually fun and strategic with actual choices.

I’m sorry, I do not understand the hype. I have no idea how this is so highly rated. Mind that I play games like MtG and am no stranger to deck building games. I was excited at the idea of the game but there’s too many issues with little joy to experience in the gameplay. There’s too many mechanics and pieces? But somehow there’s not enough pieces? If you don’t have a set of D&D dice (maybe even 4 sets) for tracking damage and ammo. The location board is too convoluted. For a card game you’re going to need a LOT of real estate to lay everything out. There’s little to no hope for success, which is what some people find fun about this game, but not me. We played 3 scenarios and didn’t enjoy any of it. Tried to give it a fair chance. If you have a way to borrow this game or play it at a board game cafe or something, do that first! Don’t spend your money until you know you’ll enjoy it.
Short and expensive, don't know how it go this high in the rankings.

The artwork is beautiful, the storyline is exciting. The game mechanics is too often unimaginative. For example, "finding a clue" simply comes down to moving your investigator to a room where there are clue tokens and performing a skill check. No explanation is given what this "clue" is, no intellectual effort was required.

What bothers us most, however, is that the game is unnecessary complex. Not enough design effort went into streamlining the game. Symbols and keywords are often poorly chosen. As a result, too much of the playing time is spent on flipping through the rulebook. I find it quite amazing that a game designer thinks he has done a great job when players need a 16-page learn-to-to-play book, a 30-page rules reference (the one you consult most) and a 7-page scenario-book to play the game.
I wanted to love this, but the rulebook is horrendous and the gameplay is frustrating.

This is a new purchase. I haven't broken the seal yet. Waiting for a quiet weekend to get into this gem.

Update I: I'm two plays into the first two scenario of Night of the Zealot. I'm still trying to get all the rules down, but I'm enjoying myself. I like how the story unfolds, round by round. How there is a clear time tracker and you have to decide whether to push on or quit while you're ahead.

Update II: I like experiencing the story more than the actual game play. Instead of moving along in a nice pace to try and solve the mystery, you are stopped every step of the way with another monster that you must fight or take on injury. You never really get a flow going, unless you consider fighting monsters a flow. Want another clue?, fight another monster. Turns out, this type of mechanic is just not my cup of tea. It's a shame, I like the story unfolding and the art is wonderful, dark but fittingly so. This, coupled with the fact that it is quite an expensive endeavor, has led me to wanting to sell or trade this one.

I’d rate it at about 3/10 if it wasn’t for the scammy economic design of the game. 35€ for only a few hours of gameplay, with ... numerous 30€ expansions with 15€ chapters (with a few dozens cards, lol). Basically what an obvious game with dlc scam design is in video game. They could have included all the expansions and chapters in the base game (wonder how the box is so big with so few content and basically no materials? Answer is easy: only one third of the box is used. ) to make it worth your money, but they had it all figured out: release scenarios and chapters at a later date, fully priced, so people need to spend ~200€ to have all the expansions and chapters.

I know a great number of people like this game, but my wife and I played it for about 5 hours and then simply came to a point where we could not follow what was supposed to happen next, and being as both our characters were within moments of dropping stone dead anyway - we packed it up and have never reopened it since. I've played games with many scores of pages of rules and dozens of games of Advanced Squad Leader (very, very long rules), but this one was a mess in my opinion.

It's very narrative and immersive, but that's just not my thing. I'd rather just read a book (and I like Lovecraft a lot). It doesn't have a lot to it gameplay wise, and I'd rather have a game that allows me to improve my deck within the session, as opposed to before and after the scenario. I guess LCGs are not my thing, which is good, because they are ridiculously expensive. I don't think I would have the patience to play this solo, and as for a 2p game, I prefer competitive play.

Super overrated game, very repetitive and stupid gameplay. The game is actually only carried by the theme and its many fans. It's actually like a good book or novel - if you're into that genre. In an objective comparison with deckbuilding games like Dominion, Paleo or Magic, this game is clearly inferior in terms of gameplay, fun and variety of decisions.

The fact that this game ranks higher than Paleo, Dominon or Magic once again clearly shows that the ranking at bgg is still a GEEK ranking and not an objective ranking of the really best games. From forums on buying path:
I'd say a great way to maximize value would be:

Revised Core (or 2 old core) -> Play.
(Do I like it? If so, then)
Dunwich Investigators -> Try different investigators, or decks with your new cards with core investigators against the Core Scenarios/Campaign -> Play, Play
(Do I feel like I need more scenarios?)
Dunwich Campaign -> Play, play, play some more.
(NOW I know which I want more of - Player cards or a new Campaign - go with what you feel like from here on out, but go SLOW)

sprinkle those Starter Investigator Packs anywhere above.
Add standalone scenarios later on in your journey - or if you have a specific use-case (i.e. you need a good one and done scenario)
Add something like "return to" boxes much later (or last) in your journey.

This was my first foray into an lcg-rpg-campaign-style board game. The permanent effect of character trauma was compelling, with Agent Roland Banks making it through the entire campaign only to end up so mentally scarred that any further adventuring would surely drive him over the edge. (Perhaps because librarian Daisy Walker intentionally engaged in battle with an Elder One so the team could have the time to send it back to its home dimension.) The overall story was adequate, connective tissue rather than a robust story with pacing and turning points, although the carry-over NPC elevated the narrative. The deck-building was limited but showed its potential for future campaigns. The mechanisms worked well, with a puzzley aspect to card combinations and teamwork, but this couldn’t compensate for the sameness to the majority of decision-making (namely, the skill checks). Ultimately, there was a procedural nature to each round, a dungeon-crawler aspect that isn’t for me. And deck construction outside the game doesn't really suit me, either. Caveat: the system is VAST, and there were a LOT of simple questions not answered in the rulebook, which made the learning more cumbersome than it needed to be.

Arkham Horror: The Card Game is somewhat similar to the earlier Cthulhu themed games from Fantasy Flight Games which initially I didn't particularly like and then learned to love, okay, enjoy. This one, however, I'm having a harder time with. I think it's because FFG have added more story through the campaign booklet and the act and agenda cards while at the same time removing the flavour that the older games have with encounter cards at each location. At the same time, they've reduced rolling a handful of dice to pulling a single token from a bag. All in all, the game is drier and more procedural than it's predecessors. Which, really, for me, isn't usually a bad thing. After all, I like Euros. And I like The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game. So I should like Arkham Horror: The Card Game. But I don't. Not really.

Once everything is set up on the table, the game plays quite well, but the preparation is a hassle. Each scenario requires:

- Preparing the deck, buying new cards with experience points, and discarding old ones
- Reading several pages of the scenario’s story and making a few decisions
- Recording decisions in the journal
- Finding and shuffling various decks for the new scenario
- Reading mythos and story cards and learning new rules for the scenario

The setup often takes longer than the actual gameplay, which isn’t ideal. Your deck often relies on a few key cards, and until you draw them, you’re mostly defenseless. The token drawing system during skill tests is also problematic. While you can influence it a bit beforehand (by using cards from your hand to improve your chances), once you draw, there’s not much you can do. You might burn three cards only to draw an auto-fail token. It’s incredibly frustrating because it often determines the success or failure of the entire mission. A much better design is when you can influence the results after the random element.

Overall Game: 8/10
Manuals: 3/10 I understand publishing a beginner/quick start guide but hiding rules therein without indexing is not the way to go. Very complex differences between cards (Assets, events, spells, traits, etc) are poorly described or not at all (there are two different ways to play/commit most cards?!)
Scenarios: 6/10 Managing Cards and Investigator decks is a nightmare (pun intended)
Solo Play: 8/10 Fully functional and enjoyable as a solo player
Difficulty Level: Very Difficult (thanks to poor manuals)

Not Worth the Price
• The basic framework of the game entails moving to locations to find clue tokens that are used to advance through the stages of the game (Acts and Agendas) before too many doom tokens accumulate: clue tokens allow progress by mitigating negative outcomes.
• There are encounter cards that represent the bad things that are happening in the story, investigator cards that represent the traits and assets of the investigators, and location cards that represent the world being explored.
• The game is organized into campaign stories consisting of multiple packs of cards that must be purchased individually at an average price of about $25; hence, each campaign can cost around $75 to $100 or more. This is a very expensive game for a mediocre gaming experience. If you enjoy stories set in the Lovecraftian universe, you’re better off buying one of the many great novels that have been written in this genre over the last century. I recommend The Laundry Files, a recent series of books by Charles Stross. They’re a mashup of Lovecraft, spy novel, and sci-fi, and would be a much better use of your entertainment dollars.

To be clear this is a review on the base game ONLY (proir to any expansion gameplay, so no, I haven't played Path To Carcosa). Before I start dumping on this game I want to be clear in my 6 out of ten rating in the sense of, that, overall, I enjoy this game to a certain extent. I really like the theme and playable investigators you can be and the cards as locations, as I was always excited to go to a new location and see what was there. But I have some MAJOR problems with this game. I'm not a whimp when it comes to coop games that are very hard to beat or difficult board games in general, but this game feels annoyingly difficult to the extent where it took away from my enjoyment of the game. I really dislike the fact that monsters don't exhaust after an attack of opportunity. It makes the game feel very restricting in what you can and can't do. The chaos bag also felt uncontrollably random at times, and it was just a big downer when you really really needed to complete one specific skill check only to find out that when you draw a chaos token that makes you fail the check and all the cards and resources you devoted to that skill check are now lost and did nothing. Gloomhaven has a similar "random" modifier to your attacks, but it didn't feel bad because there were a lot of good things you could draw from your modifier deck. I should probably stop yapping, but I really thought this was going to be better than it was, but, even after all that being said, I still think that overall this game is fine.

Arkham Horror: LCG is a marriage between classical role-playing games and collectible card games. It builds a strong narrative arc from beginning to the end and creates a nice atmosphere, but I have some issues.

First, HPL should never have entered mainstream pop culture. The guy was a racist, openly xenophobic, dealt with feelings of alienation and loneliness, he seemingly hated society along with black and jewish people and imigrants and was homophobic. That's all sad and terrible. And you take his artistic work and turn it into charming green cuddly toys and games about investigators throwing dynamite at cultists? Yeah, brilliant... All the pulpy mainstream adaptations are irresponsible dealings with the original stories and they lack complete understanding of what makes them work in the first place.

Second, organisational issues are no joke. The amount of cards that one has to manage annoyed me to no end.

Third, there's a question to be posed about consumption and consumer culture. Commercialism and consumerism are teaching us that that money and pursuit of pleasure are the greatest things in life. Getting into CCGs means money upfront, getting on a chain of endless serial purchases, related dopamine rushes, collecting stuff and and all the implications of it. I don't feel like I should nurture this idea in the furture.

Compared to AH 2e: The LCG tells a much more coherent story than AH 2e and the rules and the turn structure are clearer. In many ways it is the more robust and more refined game and less old-school, which is either good or bad, depending on where you stand on the issue.

Arkham LCG as a whole is capable of telling fantastic stories and presenting players with a huge variety of challenges, puzzles and foes. It also requires a huge investment of money to keep those fresh stories coming, and the variety of interacting mechanisms ideas by the deluge of cards makes setting up and playing games overly cumbersome. Diving into your card collection to retrieve and set up 5 different semi-randomised decks every time you want to play is irritating, as is having to check the rules and errata for the keywords sprinkled liberally throughout the game.

This rating is for the core box experience. The three introductory scenarios are, in order, fine, flawed but entertaining, and terrible. The second two actively work against core principles that they should be teaching (mitigate randomness but fail forwards; engage with the story as much as the puzzle of the game) and should have been reworked when FFG decided to rework Arkham's release model.
At one point I just stopped playing the game. I am not sure but I guess it had too little fun for the work it involves.

The best part of AH:LCG is the deckbuilding, offering plenty of decisions and creativity for all players, while still being tight in decisions.

Then comes the actual gameplay. It is good and provides an enjoyable narrative. The encounter deck and various mechanics keep the game stressful in a fun way. Resolving actions through the chaos bag greatly enhances the atmosphere. The round-to-round puzzle is great.

Different campaigns provide a varied experience, each bringing its own creative ideas. New mechanics sometimes expose the game’s unintuitive rules, though this is fairly forgivable in co-op. Some scenarios fall flat by being too easy, which is a real problem for cooperative games. On the other hand, some scenarios can be nail-bitingly hard, which is then offset with the game allowing you to fail forward. This way of balance is a hit or miss.

The campaign structure helps with telling the story and allows for deckbuilding progression between scenarios. Deck upgrades feel rewarding, with plenty of cool, new cards and story-based additions.

Most of my games are two-handed solo, which is manageable but slowed by the rule convolutions. It works in solo but shines in groups, where deck combinations and playstyles provide awesome group tension.

I do really like this system, and my issues, while annoying, can often be overlooked. Ultimately, I own every campaign and investigator expansion, with Limited deckbuilding as my favorite format.

Obwohl ich sehr sehr viele Lovecraft/Arkham-Spiele gespielt habe und großer Fan von themtisch kooperativen Spielen bin, hatte ich mit den meisten Spielen eher meine Probleme. Die meisten waren mir zu lang, zu aufwändig, zu aufgeplustert und zu pompös für relativ wenig Spiel und viel Zufall, was dann letztendlich drinsteckte. Außerdem bin ich auch kein großer Fan vom Cthulhu-Mythos und den dazu passenden Monstern (Schande über mein Haupt- ich bevorzuge aber lieber die klassischen Monster und kämpfe lieber gegen Werwölfte, Zombies, etc.). Trotzdem ist das Arkham Horror Kartenspiel das Spiel, in das ich in meinem Leben am meisten Kohle und (nach Gloomhaven) am zweitmeisten Zeit investiert habe. Eine kurze Rezension fällt mir hierbei sehr schwer, aber vielleicht kann ich dir auf dem langen Wege eher mitteilen, was das hier ist und wie ich es finde.
Was genau ist das Arkham Horror Kartenspiel? Beim Arkham Horror Kartenspiel spielen wir Ermittler, erforschen Mythen und kämpfen gegen Monster. Vor Spielbeginn bauen wir uns ein Deck zusammen, mit dem wir uns kooperativ durch eine Geschichte spielen. Es gibt die Möglichkeit einzelne Szenarien zu spielen oder (teilweise ebendiese) Szenarien als zusammenhängende Kampagne zu spielen.
Was macht das Spiel so gut? Dieses Kartenspiel schafft etwas, was bisher nur wenige Spiele für mich geschafft haben: es kombiniert für mich die drei Ts Taktik, Teamplay und Thematik. Taktik? ich habe das Gefühl, dass jede meiner Entscheidungen wichtig ist und ich mit den Konsequenzen leben muss. Spiele ich die Karte jetzt? Teilen wir uns auf? Sammel ich erstmal Ressourcen? Jede Entscheidung kann am Ende wichtig sein und das erzeugt eine tolle Spannung. Teamplay? Ich kenne mein Deck und ich kann und muss meine Entscheidungen treffen. Trotzdem beratschlage ich mich viel mit meinem Gegenüber, rätsel umher, möchte mit ihm gemeinsam das Szenario erkunden und versuche Synergien und Kombos zu schaffen. Thematik? God dammit- jede Karte macht Sinn; ich kann mir jeden Effekt bildlich vorstellen; jede Wendung bedeutet Action und hält die Spannung des Spieles aufrecht.
Welche Rolle spielt das Grundspiel? Das Grundspiel beinhält drei Szenarien, die wirklich gut sind, um Neulinge in das Spielkonzept einzuführen und um mir das ganze Drumherum schmackhaft zu machen. Leider reichen die Karten nur für zwei Decks (und die sind dann schon sehr wild zusammengewürfelt)- das eigentliche Potenzial des Deck-Buildings und auch der immersiven Kampagnen kann man erst ausschöpfen, wenn man sich einen gesamten Zyklus gekauft haft. Dann erst macht Arkham Horror richtig Spaß. Außerdem vereinfachen die vorgefertigten Decks das Spiel für mich enorm- einfach weil ich nicht eine halbe Stunde lang ein Deck zusammenzuchen muss. Ich sage es also wie es ist: die Grundbox ist scheiße, um das Spiel zu spielen! Es reicht ausschließlich zum Kennenlernen und ist nur ein erstes Beschnuppern (wie ein Ersti-Kennenlerntag in der Uni).
Ich empfehle das Spiel uneingeschränkt jedem, der sich in ein kooperatives Spiel hineinfuchsen möchte und sich mehr Abwechslung als immer nur die gleichen Dungeon Crawler wünscht. Zu zweit ist das Spiel am besten, funktioniert aber auch zu dritt und angeblich auch alleine sehr gut). Jeder sollte sich aber im klaren sein: um das Spiel als eigenständiges Hobby so richtig ausschöpfen zu können, muss man locker 300 Euro aufwärts investieren- und das ist eine ganze Menge Asche.

Mi primer y único -hasta la fecha- "living card game". Me lo recomendaron y ha colmado mis expectativas. Lo primero, MUY divertido. Es un juego que te mantiene en tensión y ganar supone todo un reto. El tema se saborea y la historia que acompaña a cada escenario y campaña hace que el juego vaya más allá de resolver un simple puzzle. La posibilidad de diseñar los mazos y que los personajes evolucionen es otro punto a favor.

La ambientación en los mundos de Lovecraft para mi es un aliciente, aunque sea desde un punto de vista completamente "pulp".

La calidad gráfica, sobresaliente, como es habitual en FFG. Y por supuesto, con todas sus expansiones pasadas, presentes y futuras, es un sacacuartos de primera, lo cual también es marca de la casa.

A very neato game. I come from the world of competitive TCGs, so I was unsure how the hell a co-op LCG would work, but I think this game not just works, but works well. Really fascinating randomization and odds pushing mechanisms all over the place seems like it would feel out of control, but I actually think that its very skill testing instead. Plus, things are generally very fail fowards. You get rewards for succeeding yes, but failing is not the end, with only minor penalties (that often make the stakes higher, and therefore more fun). In fact, I kind of love the moments that make you actively groan out loud more than anything. Reminds me of Spirit Island that way.

I like the way the actively encourages a certain type of quarterbacking, while setting hard boundaries on someone dominating the entire table. Even so, there is always lots of stuff for everyone to "do", so we all leave a chapter feeling like we accomplished something.

My big complaints about this particular product & the learn to play experience:
-Why why why are starter decks in the base box so bad. We played two chapters of NotZ, failed horribly in chapter two, looked up what were "doing wrong" online, and were extremely annoyed with the idea that you aren't supposed to play with the actual starter decks as they are, which are horribly unoptimized pieces of shit. This isn't really explicitly said anywhere in the booklet? Why are you asking me to evaluate cards / make decks before I even played the game? Do you really want me to play this piece of shit intro campaign twice?
-NotZ chapter 3 is extremely awful bullshit lmao. This is known though.
-As a reprint heavy 2nd edition product, its kind of bizarre that they put a bunch of staples from future sets in here, but still left Rogue the way it was. If the bad investigator wasn't enough, the selection of rogue cards just feels.... random. The class identity is not clear at all to me, other than having the highest evasion (which isn't very useful, at least in the combat heavy NotZ campaign). I already see Dunwich massively course correcting in this area, so why not the base box.
-There is no advice on what makes a decent team composition. There isn't really a clear answer to this tbh, but they also could have just said "Bring Seeker & Guardian" to help out the newbies.
-There are rules edge questions that I feel are pretty common, that the comprehensive rules is kind of ambiguous about.
-The learn to play booklet is laid out really weird. It runs a turn in like reverse order.

All in all very fun to play, but still kind of too expensive to recommend to others. I justify it by comparing it to the price of games like MTG, but is that really where you want to be?

Exciting and brutal story adventure game. Theme is great and I can't stop playing this because I enjoy the campaign elements and building the decks those makes each player's style unique each time. Mostly I play this as solo and playing two investigators has more synergy than just one. Also group of up to 4 players is blast.

Good to know for new players: I recommend to buy Revised core set (or sometimes 2 x old core) instead (update: there will be new core released in 2026, check that too). Good to know is, that old core includes only one copy of each different class card. Double is better, as deckbuilding allows that. Also, Revised version automatically supports up to 4 players, includes bag and some player cards that are released in Dunwich and Carcosa expansions. Also some expansions are mandatory for the true AH:LCG experience (like Campaign and Investigator expansions).

One of all-time favourites! (Rated with the expansions)

This is probably the most polished of the 3 FFG LCGs. The storyline is fleshed out. The card quality is stellar. The location and exploration design is awesome. The only design flaw that I find lazy is the Chaos Token mechanic. When a game about cooperation and strategy is at the mercy of a dice roll, or in this case a lottery draw, it feels cheap. And the cop out to that laziness is that its thematic. Nothing rips you out of your immersion of being in a cellar fighting demons faster than declaring what you want to do and then having to reach in a bag and pull out a lottery ball. Also being unable to do anything because youre stunlocked by autofail tokens. Just an all around stupid addition.

With all of that complaining aside, the game IS well made and a lot of fun. Great at 2 and3 players.

It’s a great game but one I don’t think is worth the steep cost to get into unless you really love it and want to make this your forever game.

The thematic integration and story crafting through gameplay scenarios cannot be understated and the fact that this game is co-op makes it a lot easier to table compared to something competitive like Netrunner. As your card pool grows, Arkham Horror really does provide you with ever increasing replayability that will keep you entertained for a VERY long time.

But then there’s the major downside of actually getting to that point. This game can feel like a fiddly, unforgiving, upkeep heavy luck fest with crazy setup time, especially if you don’t have many cards and thus are more limited in luck mitigation through deckbuilding. If I’m gonna have to pay as much money, time, and space as I need to in order to really get started, since you can’t just buy the core set, I better love this game. So for most people, this is just too much investment and not worth getting into. In fact, I bet this game’s geek score is pretty inflated due to selection bias.

The silver lining here is Table Top Simulator giving free full access to every card and every campaign. So if you do really like the sound of this game, try it first there. Arkham Horror Lcg is really good at what it wants to do and is worth it if you can see yourself playing this same game for a long time. Otherwise though, I would strongly think twice before committing.

edit: okay I’ve been bit by the bug and have playing a lot both on tabletop sim and IRL. The more I play, the more I can see myself playing it even more and the rating keeps going up.

Taylor's 100-point rating:

Enjoyment - 19/20 – This game is very enjoyable to play, so much so that I play this quite a bit solo as well. I really really enjoy the theme and storytelling of this game, and it truly feels like you get immersed in a wonderfully written story that you get to unfold yourself, based on your actions. So, if I enjoyed this game so much, why didn't it get a perfect score? It's a very small knit pick, I wish there were more interesting mechanics outside of the cards you play. I'll get into this a little more in the Game Mechanics section, but keep in mind, this is the smallest of knit picks.

Replayability - 12/15 – Although this game, in all reality, should get a perfect or near perfect score for replayability, I have a large issue that drops this rating 2-3 points. That issue is that the replayability, to me, seems very expansion reliant, ESPECIALLY seeing as the base game only has 3 scenarios. Most of the replayability in this games comes from two fonts, first, deckbuilding. Deckbuilding in this game creates a lot of fun and unique replayability, but it feels like you need at least 1–2-character expansions before the deckbuilding feels compelling. The second font for reliability is directly related to campaign expansions, or fan-fiction stories. I love getting a new campaign and playing through the story, and although there is some merit to replaying a campaign, I feel like it doesn’t scratch the same itch as playing a brand new story for the first time… but this requires purchasing more expansions.

Game Mechanics - 14/15 – The deckbuilding/card play mechanisms of this game are really fun and keep you very engaged throughout not only a game, but an entire campaign. My one knit pick is that I wish the mechanics outside of the cards were a little more deep/interesting. It feels like combat and investigating could be a little more unique than “Go investigate at this location that has a shroud value of ‘X’, and compare your characters stat, plus card modifiers, minus chaos token, to this value”. Again, I’m getting into some serious knit picks of a game I love, but this is what’s keeping the game from a perfect mechanics score.

Theme/Artwork - 15/15 – Can I give this game a 20/15 for its theme? If any game deserved to go above the cap of 15 for a rating, this would be the game. The horror elements are incredibly well implemented and really make you feel the weight of your character’s decision, and how you might feel in real life coming up against these atrocities. Although the category before this, I had a minor knit pick about the game’s mechanics, the game mechanics truly excel and make you feel like you’re a part of the world that’s being built in each campaign, and your actions truly have a role in unfolding the events of any given campaign.

Gameflow/Pace - 10/10 – Another perfect score there never seems to be any downtime in this game. Although play order does matter in the game, there are a few instances when players can take actions all together, but the game is still enjoyable even when you’re waiting for a partner’s turn. I believe the pacing still feels enjoyable when it’s not your turn because you all have a stake in what horrors are about to unfold. You work together as a team to beat any given scenario, and the actions of your partner can drastically change the course of actions you take when it’s your turn.

Flexibility - 8/10 – The game truly plays really well anywhere between 1-4 players. The issue is the game is hard capped at 4, and would probably get a perfect score here if there was a good variant to add more players. I will say, I love this game for solo play.

Production - 5/5 – High card quality is all you can ask for in this game, and the cards are indeed high quality.

Effort To Play - 4/5 – This game is relatively easy to set up but the reason it doesn’t get a perfect score is due to the complexity of storing both player campaign decks and monster decks. I’ve found a really good solution to this problem by using card dividers, but is still a good amount of work to organize.

Accessibility - 3/5 – This game is quite difficult to learn, especially with the added complexities of deckbuilding and knowing which cards you could have in your deck to get you out of a rough situation. With that said, to me, it feels impossible to give a co-op game anything less than a 3, seeing as it’s much easier to teach/help in a game when I’m on the same team as the people I’m teaching. This allows us to essentially dive right into the game and answer questions as they arise.

Total Score: 90/100

My personal favorite game of all time. I can always just come back to this game and find it engaging. With the way the investigators each have their own deck building restrictions + the freedom of deck building afforded by the cooperative gameplay style vs. competitive tcgs makes for one of the most rewarding deck construction experiences I've had in a card game. The scenario and campaign variety that the system and components afford is astounding. The core gameplay loop is a lot of fun and the deviations and modifications of it are even better. I love the tension/horror the game builds into it with the doom clock with the agenda deck, the chaos tokens adding variability to your tests, and the encounter deck ability to throw a wrench in your plans. Just a great game that I'd highly recommend anyone to play a full expansion campaign of to really get a feel for what it has to offer.
